posts.sub: Does liking 4Chan make you a bad person?
posts.com:
Over the last decade or more, the internet in general, and social media in particular, has changed a hell of a lot.

From forums, IRC, BBSs, through blogs, myspace, facebook, twitter, reddit etc. there has been a lot of change in this space. However, I find myself time and time again coming back here. Small subreddits serve a purpose, but generally I find most social media to be extremely boring because of the prevalent methods of forcing a single opinion on everything.

On Reddit, receiped opinion shared by the majority percolates to the top while interesting arguments are downvoted and hidden. Facebook is just shit in general. Tiktok is way too zoomer for my 30 year old ass at this point.

4Chan is a cesspit, but it doesn't ave any real sorting algorithm, and I find that is actually what makes it more interesting. But does being here make you culpable for the sins of the undoubtedly disgusting/criminal people who also frequent the site? Just looking to get some other opinions on this.

I find that Reddit is incredibly Gay, and that they lock threads and ban users for saying slightly controversial things.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I think that 4chan is built upon a fundamental paradox that brings out an interesting aspect of the human condition; a conflict between the desire for socialization and the desire for freedom from the burden of society's collated perception of an individual's identity.

See pic related, and the implication that anonymity provides said freedom, the freedom to fulfill one's wishes sans consequence. In the context of 4chan, this takes of the form of unadulterated opinion and discussion. However, one could simply do the same in a diary, hidden away and kept from the eyes of others.

Here lies the other psychological desire, the human connection. A public board, subject to the eyes of the entire world to juxtapose the faceless voices. A common need to feel heard and/or seen, despite it all.

To answer your question, no. However, will an outsider see it the same way? Also no. The precedent has been set long before the age of the internet that a negatively perceived population is the best vehicle for a tribalistic herd to rally against and for contrarian parasites to feed on.

posts.com:
I think I finally started to feel hopeful and normal and safe and happy again to the fullest degree I have in a really long time, and I couldn’t trust that. Tried to do the ol’ “Knock myself down a few pegs before the world can” thing. But that’s fucking stupid. Even if it’s ignorantly blissful reprieve leading to replenished stores to convert into output, I need to take advantage of that. At the very very least.
Hopefully I can surrender into believing sometimes the Ups are really that in fullest possible truth; not that the dips won’t come, but that there is at least a discernible difference in the waveform, that it is okay to be happy and hopeful —that space to breathe doesn’t have to mean space in my planner to pencil in worrying about or dwelling on something else.
It’s just not over until it’s over. And I really want it to be over, so we can get to the good part. Everyone. Our empire is counting on us.

Of course people can argue this is comparable to how a human produces art from inspiration, but ultimately this will have be decided in court at some point. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>27929942
>How does cystic fibrosis make you lose your sperm
The majority of men with CF are born without a vas deferens, so essentially an inborn vasectomy. Sperm quality is also significantly affected due to poor health and especially due to poor nutrition which CF patients often suffer from their pancreatic and intestinal insufficiency. Theoretically, I could have IVF done, but there's no guarantee of success, nor do I mentally feel justified in doing so because I don't want to bring a child into this world and wind up having to deal with my declining health in front of them at such a young age. I understand that it happens all the time, but I see a difference between my situation and men who get cancer and decline in front of their young children because they often don't have the foreknowledge I do about the health problems.
As for how long, I couldn't tell you. A couple years ago, I managed to get healthy enough to no longer be considered for lung transplantation, so that is huge, but still not an impossibility down the line.
>you don’t want to commit to anyone you can’t really be complaining
That's the problem, I have wanted to commit to someone but it has been self sabotage on that front. I've felt guilty about past relationships and insecure in myself so pretty much any dating situation gets sidetracked by that shit holding me back from committing.

I wanna preface this by stating that I'm a 26 yo guy. I have no degree to speak of. I failed college in my youth because of depression, social anxiey, and no one to look up to/having to keep my mental state a secret (parents are very temperamental, and I could have ended up homeless).

It seems that even if my family was willing to support me, we're poorer than I imagined, and I'm not very good soft-skills wise to get a job at an office indefinitely (social anxiey, and I'm not so keen on talking to people/selling for a living), but regardless, I wanna go to college again. I have the drive, and after scouting around I've basically boiled this decision down to two choices, and I'd like your input.

CompSci/Software engineering
>I've always dreamed of making my own videogame/working on them someday, and this would allow me to. The other option is art/illustration but it feels a bit too soulless, heavy on making connections (which I'm bad at), and not really profitable.
>Well versed on how technology works. Especially since I've noticed how so many people are tech illiterate in general.
>Wanna make passion projects regarding coding, so I'll have an incentive to pursue my degree no matter what
>Better job prospects. Will be able to work remotely, in another country, or in a cozy office.


>Degree is at an expensive uni.
>Will probably need a scholarship, which means high stress to perform well 24/7 not to let my grades drop one bit.
>Will probably need an expensive laptop/books. Piracy wont be an option every time.

cont (1/2)

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
cont (2/2)

Chem engineering
>Accessible. Can get into a cheap but very well respected college
>Just saying I'm an engineer will open up plenty of jobs, even if they're not related to my specific degree
>Sort of like chemistry
>Can probably change degrees to something profitable (pharma branch, industrial branch, etc)
>Literally SOVL. Meaningful degree and tangible results.

>Will probably be employed at some factory in the fringes of the city, commuting to a far away place everyday.
>Chemistry is an odd degree. Either there are no jobs in the city, or a few that pay very well but are outside the state and are temporary.
>Hate workshops. Hate office politics. Wont be able to rub shoulders with management very well.

As you can see, I have a bit of a bias in favor of CompSci, but I'd like your input regardless, and maybe some insider info as to what the market looks like.

I know I could become a coding god on my own (and a ton of youtube indian tutorials), but that would build me up to a glorified codemonkey,and I want a degree to make things right.

I think your dad cares about his children no matter who their mother is. I think he didn't want to drop her. I think he wanted to do right by this child and show love even if it could only be through financial support. Fault lies entirely with your dad, not with the girl, and presumably not with her mother (assuming she didn't know he had a family when this happened). You can still love someone and acknowledge that they did something wrong, people are only human. We must live with our mistakes, but you can love in spite of them and that's your choice.

Now he's at the point where he wants her to see that she has a family when she likely only had her mother's side for her whole life, he does care about this girl. It is tough for your family, and I assume he's only doing it now that there's some level of acceptance that the events have occurred. He is putting pressure on all of you, and it's because of his own infidelity, but it sounds like he's taking this risk on his life with all of you out of a desire to do right by this innocent girl, not because he's trying to normalize his wrongdoing. I'm sure he is just as stressed and worried about what he's doing knowing that it's straining the family, but he feels strongly about giving this girl what he feels he owes her, and I think that at least is understandable. Ignorance is bliss, but I feel like it would be a shame to truly discard an innocent child.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>27929791
volunteer. do something that fulfills you or occupies your time. ideally something that gets you around people, since it seems that's the main problem here.

do you like animals? volunteer at an animal shelter. start striking up convos with random people. if you see the same people everyday at the gym, just say whats up, don't expect anything of it. go to outside work events if you have them.

basically, start saying yes to opportunities, anon. and if you're early 20s and reading this, even if whatever you got invited to sounds shitty, saying yes is how you live life to the fullest. don't wait to do it when you get fit or whatever, just do it now.

the above is something i'm working on actively, and doing significantly better at now. for the social skills portion i can actually help a lot here. for reference i legitimately thought i was autistic from the ages of 16-22. only over the past year have i changed my perspective. i was just socially stunted. probably like a lot of you reading this.

fact is most of you guys are actually deep down probably genuinely good people, you're just burnt out or angry at life for whatever reason. some of you might have very good reasons for that. the thing is, i'll be blunt here, nobody cares. you weren't dealt a fair hand, fine, but that doesn't change anything. you're in the situation you're in now, and you have to accept that.

one thing that really helped me was just accepting that and being genuine with people. i don't talk about people behind their back, i don't exclude people, and i give people compliments when i can. on the flip side i don't really hold back on whatever joke i want to tell, which obviously im on 4chan so you guys can tell my sense of humor. sometimes they land sometimes they dont, but i have had MULTIPLE people tell me to my face over the past few months alone that i'm easy to talk to, a good friend, someone they feel they can share secrets with, etc.

this is getting long so ill cont.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>27930698
one thing a lot of you guys struggle with is social anxiety. i don't really have a tip for you other than you just need to get over it. some of you guys have it so bad it's crippling, which i empathize with, so the best bet there would probably be to take baby steps. stop wearing headphones in public, smile at the pretty girl you see walking down the street, call customer support instead of asking google, things like that. i didnt have it as bad as some of you so i will be honest and say i have some privilege there. but i'm still on fucking 4chan so clearly it wasn't like i was healthy.

anyway, back to conversations. this sounds like bullshit but ill be real, i think one thing that kind of helped me was listening to podcasts. comedy ones specifically. i think the brutal honesty of some of the guys on TAFS or MSSP brought out this inner confidence in me that like "if these guys can say some of this embarrassing shit to thousands of people, my stories to a group of 2-3 people aren't that bad."

basically, actively try to be genuine and nice, compliment people (but don't be fake about it), but don't be a pushover. it's okay to crack an edgy joke, if people like you and they don't think it's funny they'll typically forgive you pretty quickly when you say "sorry im retarded i thought it was funny"

social situations are very easy once you start having them on a regular basis. hopefully this helps someone.

>27
ill be blunt. we are in different points in our lives. what worked for me might not work for you, but ill tell you how i think about these things anyway. maybe you can relate, maybe you can't. but it can't hurt to try if you haven't already (that's the part about saying yes to things)

>do you think it would be worth looking into getting involved with something like that?
answer is yes. always yes. and don't give up after your first time if you don't like it or don't make a friend your first day or something. try to go in with the goal of just helping people. you're there to volunteer, after all. but keep in mind you can help the people you're volunteering with, too. if something is heavy and that cute girl can't pick it up? you've been gymming, this is your time to shine.

the reason close friendships form when people are younger, in the army, or related situations is because traumatic and/or new experiences help bond people closer together. even if you are fundamentally different from the other person, those shared experiences help you understand the other person regardless of political views or whatever other bullshit people hate each other for. volunteering is kind of like that.

>i grew up not having friends and being bullied for being different
we're on 4chan, kind of figured.

>do i just need to throw myself into uncomfortable situations and keep making mistakes and trying stuff?
pretty much. and then when you inevitably fuck up you can joke about it.

>my only worry is that i'm getting too old to make meaningful relationships
it's never too late. you won't form the same relationships you might have in high school or college, but you'll form healthier and longer lasting ones. don't go in expecting to change it overnight, just try your best to be better.

>i just freeze up in those situations and i'm not sure how to improve this
i dont freeze up much anymore, but asking questions helps. and chances are if you don't have questions, you know what they're talking about and you can relate somehow. say what's on your mind. stop caring about how you're perceived, if that's the issue. just say it.

the cool thing about opening up and being more social is once you start having more and more interactions with people, you can draw on those and bring them up in conversations with others you talk to.

if someone has a hobby you've never heard of, you can ask them all about it, and the next time you talk to someone that has that same hobby now you know all about it and they'll talk your ear off and you'll make their day. bet they'll never forget you.

people are beautiful. life is wonderful. anon, you have something to share with the world. don't live life without sharing your story. i guarantee you have more to share than you're giving yourself credit for.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>27922705
You'll feel groggy, sleep a lot, eat a lot, and not have much energy for the first few weeks. It takes a while to feel fully normal again and get rid of the brainfog. Like, a month or two. If it's something you want to do, you'll have to tough it out. It was totally worth it for me, though. Just remember that your appetite will be crazy, and you're probably not used to having to watch what you eat. I used to come home from work and eat a whole pot of pasta, pizza, chicken nuggets, whatever because it makes your metabolism so fast and you don't eat much during the day. When I quit, I gained 30 lbs. within a few months and am still trying to get rid of it. Just something to keep in mind. Baby carrots are nice to snack on, and potatos are good for keeping you full without many calories. That's the only part that sucked about quitting after the first month or so.

If you have time, you could cut your dosage in half for a while before stopping completely, which might lessen some of the symptoms.

ADHD generally is a scam. Not saying there's nothing at all to it. But over-diagnosis and over-medication are major problems. "Oh, your kid is bored in some cookie cutter class literally tailored to the lowest common denominator? Must be ADHD. Let's give them hardcore stimulants so they can become drug addicts in adulthood." "You're actually just depressed and don't understand why you're seen as a commodity by every institution and 90% of the people in your life? Have some speed."

>it's pretty much the same thing as meth

People say that so often it sounds dumb, but it really is true. Even prescription doses get you fucking high. It looks like OP is on 40mg per day of short-acting Adderall versus extended release. They put me on 40mg of XR when I was twelve. I was literally scratching and clawing at my desk, high out of my fucking mind as a twelve year old, but because I was quiet and quick to answer questions in class, everyone thought it was a big breakthrough for me or something. Never even questioned it. Three or four hours of sleep a night, suicidal. I probably wouldn't be on fucking 4chan right now if I was able to live my life normally. lol

imo, the benefits of being able to keep your head down and silently do your tasks aren't a path to success anyway, unless it's for school or you do something independent/very technical. It makes a lot of people awkward and overly agreeable (not some Jordan Peterson faggot) if there's any level of communication involved. Honestly, try negotiating a raise on it. See if you get that promotion when people see you as that quiet, shy, studious, etc. guy. I take responsibility for making a mess of my life, but that's one thing that I feel failed by as a child.

Should be for legal adults only, rarely prescribed, and in lower doses.

posts.sub: Woman is madly in love with me, but I'm not that physically attracted to her.
posts.com:
I've known this woman for five years; she's stupid in love with me. I like her a lot too and would describe her as my best friend. She isn't ugly, in fact she gets a lot of male attention, but she just isn't exactly my type. I just don't feel deep physical attraction to her---I rarely feel this with anyone, I've only felt it maybe 2-3 times in my life.
But maybe feeling deep physical attraction is a meme and it isn't what counts in a long-term relationship. Looks fade and you grow old and disgusting regardless. I don't know.
She tells me daily that she'd marry me instantly if I asked. That all she wants is a quiet life with me and a lot of that appeals to me; I like the simplicity of it and just forgetting the world and things are very easy with her.
On the counter side, I'm not sure I want a life-long relationship. I like solitude and being alone. I've never had a proper, proper long-term relationship and have never lived with anyone. I think I get annoyed by other people pretty readily and the thought of having to wake up next to someone and deal with their presence doesn't appeal to me.
I think I'm conflicted about it because I really don't believe in the romanticized "perfect love" or "perfect relationship". I think relationships as a whole are pretty ugly and full of faults; maybe the faults I perceive in this situation are worth dealing with. It feels like things like deep physical attraction may be overrated (and, also, transient regardless). Maybe what I have with her is at good as it gets. Of course I'm not sure I even want a long-term relationship regardless, with anyone.
Another qualm I have is that while I've repeatedly told her I don't know what I want, I think she's really betting on me coming through in the end and that if I say "no" her whole world will fall apart. I'm worried she'll kill herself or something.
So yeah, what do?

posts.sub: When should one have faith rather than rationality as a guide forward?
posts.com:
Hypothetical scenario: the idea of being a clown beckons to you. Clowning has always been something intriguing, so you are thinking about undergoing the steps in order to become a clown. You then think about how you have heard people don’t like clowns, which makes you worry about how that would affect your ability to make money. You think about how difficult clown college will be able to pay off. You think about whether you would be able to survive on clowning alone. You check the Bureau of Labor Statistics, and the employment rate for clowns in your state has been going down for the last few years. With all of that buzzing through your head, you decide not to become a clown. Your desire gnaws at you as you go back to being confused about where you want to go in your life.

This is a situation where one could use faith; to go forth despite the reasons presented not to. You could be a clown, but you allowed your reasons to sway you. What should decide whether to use faith or not?

>>27928724
It depends on what your rejection is based upon. Try finding out what is the main object/reason of your peers' rejection towards you and question yourself if it is something worth changing or not. Sometimes it's also something quite simple: just talk to the people that reject you what the actual fuck is wrong with them, sometimes these people are just socially clueless or extremely insecure and they don't actually know how to navigate social situations either. But Imho surviving validation is more about finding a sense of community you share with other friends. Try finding people with the same interests as you and give it a go.
